descriptionSet.description: This advertisement for William Jacks & Co. Paints of Bombay shows a set of different furniture consisting of a bed, an armchair, a mirror, lamp and carpet along with matching blue curtains.

inscription.text: As the SUN colours flowers so ART colours LIFE
For a RESTFUL ATMOSPHERE use the artistic shades of William Jacks & Co.'s PAINTS
(made by Sissons Bros. of Hull, estd. 1803) including "Tungaline" - "Hall's Distemper" - "Renoflor" - "Bonoglos" - "Flatomur," Etc.
paint and fibrous plaster decorations executed by William Jacks & Co.'s Paints & Contracts Dept. Bombay.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

description-en: This advertisement for William Jacks & Co. Paints of Bombay shows a set of different furniture consisting of a bed, an armchair, a mirror, lamp and carpet along with matching blue curtains. (gs/tb)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This advertisement for William Jacks & Co. Paints and Contracts of Bombay in 1934 offers a vision of carefully matched modern furniture, drapes and wall-to-wall carpeting brought together into a cohesive whole. Perhaps speaking to consumer anxiety about how to tastefully combine diverse commodities in the modern home, the ad copy urges viewers to chose the “artistic shades” of William Jacks' paints in order to evoke a “restful atmosphere” in their homes. The most elaborately imagined home interiors appear, however, not in advertisements depicting commodities for sale, but in ‘calendar art’ images that evoke the meaning of home more broadly. Often designed to ornament calendars issued by businesses to customers and friends, such images also circulated independently as posters suitable for framing. Printed in bright colors at low cost, ‘calendar art’ circulated widely in mid-twentieth century India, gracing the walls of homes and offices alike, across the middle classes. As such, this popular art form brought an idealized vision of the modern home to those whose material realities might have been quite different, offering a glimpse into what a better future might hold, or a space in which to imagine a life of plenty. The future imagined in these images differed from those of earlier periods. Specifically, images of the modern home mark the shift that Sandria Freitag notes in her essay “Consumption and Identity” from ethnographic representations of the everyday to an imagined everyday in which modern selves were forged through consumption of novel goods; the same images also document the transition Arvind Rajagopal notes in his (forthcoming) essay “The Commodity Image in the (Post)Colony” from overtly religious imagery in advertisements to, around the time of Indian independence, “the secular pieties of official nationalism.” For the ideal homes of calendar art are rooted firmly in consumer desires not lived realities, even as they declare those desires to be open to all religions, thanks to a careful excision of overt religious references or imagery. (Abigail McGowan)(gs)
